Is Zero Trust and SSO a contradiction?

Zero Trust is much more granular. Even if an account is authenticated and authorized to take certain actions, there are oftentimes going to be additional security checks made as the account is taking those actions AND there will also potentially be reauthorization checkpoints as well as other security challenges presented during a session.You can do some googling/reading about Zero Trust and you'll quickly realize ZT and SSO are not a contradiction, oxymoron, or however you want to look at it. ZT goes much deeper.

Zero Trust as the name implies avoids trust relationships between services.This is not true, and your understanding of zero trust is flawed. In a zero trust model, the user account would be evaluated at each service interaction, while the account could be the same across each service, and the auth would be re-evaluated each time they access a service. Your policies should be evaluating anomalies for re-auth or re-mfa if things are outside of normal, for instance, if a user suddenly accesses their account/service from a new Geo location.Now if an attacker has the user's password, and their phone... well, there's not much you can do other than evaluate and isolate the account based on actions they take if malicious.

SSO and Zero Trust can coexist. Zero Trust isn’t about eliminating trust, but continually verifying it. SSO simplifies access while Zero Trust ensures continuous validation at each access point. They’re complementary, not contradictory :D

SSO is a technical solution. Zero Trust is a strategy or concept.It entirely depends on how SSO is implemented, the processes and policies you have in place, and removing all implicit trust from the above.

Zero Trust is a thing you do. Like parenting, you never actually finish doing Zero Trust.When you’re doing Zero Trust properly you have completely eliminated IMPLICIT TRUST that lasts longer than a single transaction.Every flow is inspected. Every interaction is validated. Forever.Using SSO and MFA is part of that. But the trust relationship between parties is ephemeral. It must be validated each and every time.The lack of clarity on the Zero Trust concept is why blue teams keep taking one giant loss after another.If you run a network defense organization please just get over it. There are no shortcuts. There is only hard work. Anything else will continue to deliver you more compromises and more avoidable losses.

Even in a ZT environment there is always some form of trust, however certain conditions (that assert trust) have to be met before you grant access and for the latter you have to decide upon what level of trust is sufficient (based on the type of resource) to provide access or not. There just shouldn’t be any implicit trust. SSO doesn’t equal implicit trust, which I think you confuse it with.If your whole environment relies on just username + password authentication (and now I disregard authorization and least privilege principle) and these are compromised then you have the same problem as with SSO right?In a proper ZT environment you take additional factors such as location, device, device health/status, time, risk scores, etc. into consideration to determine whether you grant access. Preferably dynamic, risk-based (in line with your risk appetite) and in real time :)

"Zero Trust" (the concept) is a misnomer, "conditional trust" or "limited trust" better describe what the concept actually represent.For this reply I assume we're talking the NIST ZTA definition.SSO is directly compatible with ZTA as the SSO IdP is considered a PEP for identity posture. 2.1.6 covers this:All resource authentication and authorization are dynamic and strictly enforced before access is allowed. This is a constant cycle of obtaining access, scanning and assessing threats, adapting, and continually reevaluating trust in ongoing communication. An enterprise implementing a ZTA would be expected to have Identity, Credential, and Access Management (ICAM) and asset management systems in place. This includes the use of multifactor authentication (MFA) for access to some or all enterprise resources. Continual monitoring with possible reauthentication and reauthorization occurs throughout user transactions, as defined and enforced by policy (e.g., time-based, new resource requested, resource modification, anomalous subject activity detected) that strives to achieve a balance of security, availability, usability, and cost-efficiency.3.3 covers Trust Algorithms, one that integrates UEBA (which they call "contextual") and one that doesn't. They give an example of a case where an attacker compromises an account and tries to stay stealthy:Ideally, a ZTA trust algorithm should be contextual, but this may not always be possible with the infrastructure components available to the enterprise. A contextual TA can mitigate threats where an attacker stays close to a “normal” set of access requests for a compromised subject account or insider attack. It is important to balance security, usability, and cost-effectiveness when defining and implementing trust algorithms. Continually prompting a subject for reauthentication against behavior that is consistent with historical trends and norms for their mission function and role within the organization can lead to usability issues. For example, if an employee in the HR department of an agency normally accesses 20 to 30 employee records in a typical workday, a contextual TA may send an alert if the access requests suddenly exceed 100 records in a day. A contextual TA may also send an alert if someone is making access requests after normal business hours as this could be an attacker exfiltrating records by using a compromised HR account. These are examples where a contextual TA can detect an attack whereas a singular TA may fail to detect the new behavior. In another example, an accountant who typically accesses the financial system during normal business hours is now trying to access the system in the middle of the night from an unrecognizable location. A contextual TA may trigger an alert and require the subject to satisfy a more stringent confidence levelIf we take Entra ID as an example, Sign-in Risk somewhat satisfies this point, as with Conditional Access in Continual Evaluation mode, you can block unusual sign-ins. We're not quite there if the attacker:Has compromised the victim's machineLogs in at the same rate, at the same hours and to the same apps as the victimManages to not get caught by any of the other PEP mechanisms (EDR, NAC)

Zero trust is never a zero 😉 At the end, it's always about compromises for usability and productivity, and nothing is black & while.On the other hand - even with SSO, there is an authentication process, and that checkpoint is when you can look for irregularities (anomaly detection).I used to be specialized in a field (Citrix) where this was a hot topic when zero trust was introduced.For the context, SSO for me is referring to the authentication method (seamless), not to a single Identity Provider. For customers that raised this concern, we simply switched to the explicit authentication.
ZT is another layer. It is not a contradiction to SSO.

ZT isn't an authentication scheme. ZT assumes all authentication schemes are flawed. A ZT strategy would restrict a user only to the resources they have access so that if the authentication is compromised the bad actors are still limited to what they can access. Then couple that with least privileged and role-based access policies. Then perhaps additional authentication at the resource level, if practical.
To some extent yes. Zero trust requires you to trust several companies, especially the identity providers.The IdP also complies with governments, may be hacked and so on.

Cybersecurity, by its very nature, is full of compromises, some of which can be seen as contradictions. The reason for this is simple, because cybersecurity aims to strike a balance between competing concerns. It's in the very foundation of the CIA triad. The question isn't "how do you totally secure this thing?" The real question is "how do you secure this thing the best while still allowing people to use it to do what they need to do?"So yes, SSO is a bit of a contradiction in regards to zero trust. But it gives the users an easy platform to log into multiple systems they need to use while giving security teams extra controls to maintain the security of the systems, so it's an important part of a good zero trust setup. Not because it's a contradiction, but because it increases two parts of the CIA triad at the same time, which benefits the entire organization.

No, zero trust and single sign-on (SSO) are not inherently contradictory. Zero trust is a security framework that assumes no trust by default and requires verification from everyone, even those inside the network. SSO, on the other hand, enables users to access multiple applications with a single set of credentials.In a zero-trust environment, SSO can be implemented securely by incorporating multi-factor authentication (MFA) and continuous monitoring to ensure that access remains authorized. This combination enhances security by reducing the reliance on traditional perimeter defenses.

Cybercriminals crave cookies, not passwords

Cookie theft is not a new tactic to bypass authentication – valid cookies can be imported into a criminal’s system, spoofing the victim’s device. However, this method is on the rise since many users now use multi-factor authentication, making it harder to access accounts with stolen passwords, Hilligoss explained in an interview with Cybernews.And it may become worse.“It's much bigger than just Google. Cookie theft has been so pervasive for so long, and people are really concerned about their usernames and passwords. I feel like very few people really understand how serious cookie theft is and how difficult it is to prevent,” Hilligoss said.Hilligoss assures that Google accounts are one of the most attractive to criminals as they contain a lot of critical personal, tax, and other information and can also be used to reset passwords of other services.“If I get into your Gmail account, I bet you I can reset your Facebook password using your Google account. I do that in the middle of the night. You're not going to realize it until the morning. Now I've got control of your Facebook,” Hilligoss explained to Cybernews. “And the criminals do this every day.”Crooks can use powerful information stealers like Lumma for just $250 per month without any tech knowledge.

Pretty simple. You send a request to our team, we run the pentest. At the end of the month, we charge for total number of pentests. Pay as you go vs full time staffing.

In the UK it tends to mean "on demand" testing, rather than project based testing and isn't crowdsourced.Our PTaaS is essentially a pool of days that a customer can draw from at any time they like, via a request portal. That request is serviced via the same staff and methodologies as if they were engaging on a per project basis.Typically it's software developers or larger orgs that utilize the service as they like to test specific releases/changes that require a wider context, but not a wider test.So it can be a specific API endpoint of a web app that's had a change, needs a test to verify and release to prod. Rather than go through a full scoping every time they do something, they can just request that specific endpoint is tested.

We offer PTaaS. We provider quarterly testing on an app. This model works a bit better because every engagement is typically a pen test and maybe a retest or two. During those retest we look to see if you fixed the stuff we found. Reality is we probably found one or two more through the course of the retest. However, it’s outta scope. With PTaaS we’ll just essentially schedule four retest for the year. Then during the retest or quarterly engagements, we’ll look for the ones you should have fixed and identify any new ones.For businesses, it enables to have folks on hand annually vs looking for out sourced services to fit the immediate need. For customers it allows them a little more visibility without the cost to do it as much.I think it has its benefits. I’d buy it if I was a manager and funding allowed for it

It is the responsibility of the business to make business decisions. This includes more than just security. Further, not all vulnerabilities are equally important.It is your responsibility to ensure that vulnerabilities are appropriately understood (you did include the severity, why it's that severe, and what damage could be done, right?).It's also your responsibility to ensure vulns are properly reported. What are your internal reporting requirements? Who does your company's process say is allowed to accept the level of risk that these vulns represent?If the business wants to accept the risk, it's your responsibility to cover your butt. Get the risk acceptance in writing.If that's all done, then you have a choice: * let the vuln(s) be and do your work * quit * fix the vulns anyhow, and risk breaking other stuff, risk getting reprimanded or fired * see if there's a reporting agency that you can inform (who might already be aware of the vuln). This also risks retaliation (even if illegal).

So before you go down a rabbit hole in this, there are some things you should know as a starting point.1) IT and CyberSecurity are definitely not the same and the approach to auditing different areas of technology will be materially unique.2) It's important to have a process, procedures, and framework to how you approach an audit far before you start evaluating tools3) The tools are irrelevant without #2. The tools are not the answer to performing a good audit. Audits live and die by the questions you ask. Better questions = Better potential outcomes and less gaps in the information you are capturing.4) Even the best auditors/audit tools can fall prey to fabricated artifacts. The tools are NOT going to prepare you nor mitigate for this.
